title: Trump says illegal immigration on the southern border has dropped by 61% since election day.
text: President Donald Trump told Kentucky supporters to focus on their basketball team and allow him to take care of the rest, such as securing borders and illegally expelling immigrants in the country. "We will build, that's right, a great great border wall, and we will stop the drugs that flow into our country and poison our youth and many others. Trump said March 20th. "Many of them come from the southern border. Since my election day, we have already reduced illegal immigration on the southern border by 61 per cent, think about it, 61 per cent, and we have not yet started." Trump boasts about 40 percent of the decline in illegal immigration in his first month in office. We've mostly evaluated that right. It now extends the comparison to November to show greater reductions. The arrests of border patrols at the United States-Mexico border declined by 60 per cent from November 2016 to February 2017, but immigration experts caution against assuming that the declines were the sole result of the Trump policies. On 8 March, the Ministry of National Security published illegal border crossing data showing that in the month of the presidential election, November 2016, 47,210 arrests were made by the Border Patrol. In February 2017, there were 18,762 concerns, a 60 percent decrease. Total south-west border concerns decreased by about 63 per cent between November 2016 and February 2017. The Department of National Security has defined total arrests as those carried out by border patrols between ports of entry and inadmissibility at ports of entry defined by the United States Customs and Border Protection Office. We have asked United States Customs and Border Patrols to obtain arrest data from election day until the day before Trump's speech in Kentucky, but the Agency has said that it provides statistics by month, not specific dates and time frames. It should be noted that this past autumn there was a seasonal increase in unauthorized border crossings, as said by Christopher Wilson, Deputy Director of the Mexico Institute at the Wilson Centre.
